about 25kg. Can't test am german noguns fag, asked the youtuber techthisoutmeow and zna productions to test my method. Various types of glass filament layers with epoxy/polyester resin can be made into 3a armor. Still waiting for a response. It's good against slashing and bashing too. Doubt a professional samurai with a ten thousand fold katana can cut trough a full plate.
>>2509382
see pic rel for basic idea that applies to all pieces I made. I dunno how you would print that. Gonna paste my an explanation

It consists of a backer plate (9 light + 9 heavy layers), porcelain shards and a topper (3 +3) encasing the ceramics. Wanted to use 2 offset layers of ceramics, instead I placed the first and additional shards on what I deemed crucial parts of the armor.

This is the basic method for all armor parts I made, a full plate with porcelain for my mask, forearms and torso, the rest consists only of the backer type plate, 18 layers of sandwiched light and heavy glass cloth.

Made a visor from 1cm thick polycarbonat. Went trough some trial and error while attempting to heat bend it. Made a bubble free curved piece with our oven, the trick is to heat it up to 150c first and frequently open the door to let out steam, after a while turn it up to 175c. I want to thank thermoplastic anon for that info again. Another thanks to soap bar anon, scrub a bar of soap then wipe with a dry towel on glassy surfaces like glasses you don't want to fog up with your breath, it really works.

>>2509676
show examples of how this could be made, 3d printers are definetevly cool, but I noticed a trend where people will simply assume that a printer can print anything. How would you measure out your face this way? I did with simple gypsum bandages. And then print it how? Carbon fibres? For costs, a 33cm x 33cm rectangle plate costs about 15€ in material costs, the groin plate has this size. thats 9 + 9 patches of the heavy a d light glass filament. 1m2 can be cut into 9 patches. 1m2 of glass weave costs about 3-5€, so about 3 for the light and 5 for the heavy, 8€ total for the weave. Epoxy resin can be expensive, cheapest I found was 11€ per kg. for a 33cmx33cm plate with 18 layers of mixed weaves I needed 750g of epoxy, so about 7-9€ or something. Now you got a basic plate for what 15-20€. Porcelain is the best worst ceramic for balistic protection, you can source that for free. Add another glass weave for spalling protection above that to stop porcelain fragments from flying everywhere and boom you got a decent plate I'd say. 25€ max.

>>2511923
the protective gear part is a different beast. the orthopaedic gear is to prevent knee injury from missteps or non optimal posture. same goes for the lumbar belt.
even the cheap aldi versions do their job.

joint injury is the number one eliminator of modern troops.

for the fit: add a padded comfortable belt strap with some semi-rigid plate support. this way you circumvent the spine being loaded and free your lungs more. putting padding on the shin lower side, so it rests better on the shoe, can make the bug a feature.

some light knee pads could help with the armor and hard knuckle or sand gloves would add some necessary hand protection.

for the groin plate: try to cut it int an inverted trapezoid (basicly upside down chest plate shape). then it moves more easily when walking. the two removed pieces can be added as belt flaps/ armor skirt pieces.

>>2513688
For maximum efficiency, cut the fat out and chop it into ~1cm cubes. Put it in a pot with some water to cover and heat it to a simmer. After a few hours all the fatty acids will be rendered out of the tissue, then you sift the chunks out and let the liquids harden. The fat layer separates and floats on the water. To clean it just scrape the grimy bits off the bottom of the solid fat layer and put it back in a pot with fresh water and a generous handful of salt, bring it to a simmer and stir it a bit, let it cool and repeat until pearly white. Finally melt the fat down and insert a wick. There you go, odorless human candle.
Human fat is about 7700kcal/kg which is a lot better than wood pellets which generally sit around 4300kcal/kg. You only need a small fraction of that energy to refine it.

To make soap all you need to do is weigh your human tallow, then bring it to about 50°C. Take 26.82% of your fat weight in distilled water and 13.41% in pure lye and dissolve it in the water (do it with good ventilation or die). It will heat to almost boiling so let the mixture come down to around 50°C also, then dump it in the liquid fat and blend it with an immersion blender until it turns into a sort of paste. Scoop that out into whatever mold you like and let it sit for a day, then demold it and let it air dry for 2-4 weeks.

Why teflon? Why bedliner for bonding? Line X actually is bombproof, mythbusters made a vid about that, discussed this in thread #1 or 2 I think. The company by the same name actually has a specialized type of coating called pax- something. They use that for bombproofing government buildings. But you can't simply buy either of these products in a can. A shame. Only certified paintshops who are in contract with Line - X get that stuff and are allowed to coat projects wih it.

I wrote ZNA productions and techthisoutmeow multiple times, donated to their patreon. Wanted them to build and shoot test panels with my method. Mentioning it again, 9 light + 9 heavy layers and additionally porcelain + another 3 heavy and 3 light ontop. No further responses for about two months or so.

But thankfully a german hansguns offered to test it for me, I'll be sending him 2 such testpanels after xmas. I've gained some doubts of the success of my plates delivering what I hope for, because I did something different. I didn't vacuum press the plates during curing. My theory is, the epoxy itself should stay where it is and not be pressed out excessively. Further, I think a pressed conventional plate has it disadvantages too. The layers are already then pressed together and it' s maybe easier to penetrate them this way.

So I actually made a plate like this when I was a teenager. I took a piece of polycarbonate, placed ceramic tiles on top and then laminated the whole thing with many layers of fiberglass and polyester resin. Then I went to a gunfag board and asked some one to shoot it for me.

The results were not good, basically the only thing that didn't penetrate fully was .22LR. I don't remember exactly what he shot it with but I recovered the jacket of a large caliber pistol, possibly 45ACP and a small rifle round, most likely .223. Simply put, ceramic tiles are not hard enough to stop rifle rounds and while they may be able to fragment pistol rounds, they then turn into shrapnel that blows right through the backing. The whole thing was too stiff to work even as 3A armor and while polycarbonate is very tough, it cannot withstand the high impulse of a bullet impact, it basically tore open like a flap and let everything through.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2497894
I've been down this road before. Don't do it. Electrical stuff is the absolute worst to try to keep organized, since every type of thing (resistors, caps, connectors, fuses, relays, ICs, sensors, LEDs, the list goes on) has 100 different subtypes, and often each one of those subtypes has a subsubtype. When you start putting shit in tackle boxes, unless you're very careful about how you organize it, you might as well throw it away, because you're never going to see it again.

I've found the best way to avoid clutter and minimize "forgotten items" is to maximize literal visibility of your stuff. Genuinely, taking the doors off of a bunch of my floor-to-ceiling storage cabinets was one of the smartest things I've ever done. Those harbor freight small parts organizers can be a blessing and a curse. If you're going to use one, you need to label each drawer, otherwise it just becomes a garbage container, and you might as well throw it away.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2497889
you're gonna want a multi-layer approach for top hoarding. First you line the walls with peg-board. Then at chest level you're gonna want work-bench tier table/shelving that goes along the sides of the work room. You can then subdivide the lower sections into actual drawers or cubby hole spaces for large containers or tool chests. Now since you didnt finish the cieling you're gonna wanna get some cordage and hang stuff off of it, like baskets full of gloves and shit. We arent done yet, because that ladder in the corner can be used to access the rafters, where you are going to shove all the shit you will never use but dont want to throw away up there. Get some 2x6s and make some light shelves that fit between the rafters. Dont put anything heavy up there though, because realistically the framing of your roof isnt designed to hold weight in that direction but its fine if its just a few hundred pounds. probably.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>1. Is there any real reason to spend big on a "high security" lock over your stock-standard cylinder? Are thieves really picking locks in the real world?
We've had business owners at my work ask us to put high-security locks on buildings with floor-to-ceiling glass walls and doors. The security level of your lock should match the security level of the rest of your security system. Most actual criminals (in America) don't bother to pick locks because it's a skill that requires patience, and if criminals had patience, they wouldn't be criminals. They're going to put in the least amount of effort possible. Your advantage as a homeowner is that you can control how high that lower limit is.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2518012
>Are thieves really picking locks in the real world?
not much, but what some theives do is make copies of keys from where they work after getting access to them legitimately as part of their job or by sneaking them off the premises and putting them back after getti g copies made.
Security locks minimize the ability to do this by restricting and documenting who gets blanks at the locksmith level, so if you keep close rein on who has a key you can minimize inside theft jobs by unknowns or disgruntled terminations using a spare key.
If a key gets away though you'll need to get new cylinders and keys, and some brands will remove restrictions on older blanks when they stop selling those models, or just after a decafe or so to force everyone to upgrade cylinders to maintain the security restrictions.
IOW its kind of like a subscription service that needs to be renewed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2518012
>Is there any real reason to spend big on a "high security" lock over your stock-standard cylinder?
For a house, no. Stay away from bullshit electronic smart locks. A lot of them can be beaten with rare earth magnets, plus the backup cylinders are baby-tier easy to pick. I've seen people open fingerprint locks with a photocopy of someone's fingerprint. Just get a regular Schlage and remember to keep it locked.

>How difficult is it to replace a lock yourself, without having to pay a locksmith?
Very easy. All you need is a phillips screwdriver. Take the long screws out of the old one, pull it apart, replace the guts, slap the new one on and line it up, screw back together. I can do them in about 15 minutes.

>>2518024
This. Get a nice solid door, dead pin the hinges, and reinforce the frame to discourage kicking in.
Add some sort of basic alarm system. They even have sensors now that will alarm and text your phone if the door is opened. The more bullshit the crackheads have to get through the less likely they are to try.
Keep your drapes closed so they can't case your house or see your bigass TV. Don't put boxes from expensive things in your trash, find a dumpster somewhere to toss them in. Don't advertise that you have shit worth stealing. Make sure sliding doors and windows have nigger bars wedged in them so they can't be forced from outside.

>>2518096
Follow basic common sense. When you buy a new house change the locks immediately before you do anything else. You have no way of knowing how many people have the old keys.
For businesses make sure you get keys back if you fire someone and cancel their alarm codes as soon as they leave. For job boxes and other storage locks replace all of the locks a couple times a year. Don't reuse old locks just pitch em. Security cameras with offsite storage are a good idea.

>>2523747
Doug would of course claim that that pic just shows how needlessly complicated a typical bermuda rigged boat is and that junks are superior on that count alone but a) that's not a typical bermuda rig even for something intended for singlehanding and doesn't *need* that many lines led aft...and b) junk running rigging isn't necessarily simple, especially when set up for singlehanded operation.
Picrel is the boat of the guy who did more to advance singlehanded offshore sailing and junk rig adaptation to modern/western hull forms than anyone, just as an example of what a proper setup looks like.
He was a legendary yachtsman and pioneer in offshore sailing techology and junk rigging who proved his ideas with multiple blue water passages, I doubt that Doug would even recognize his name if he heard it.
Also worth noting that after that boat was proven seaworthy and safe in a number of Atlantic crossings, it sank on an Atlantic crossing-

"Jester competed in the first OSTAR Transatlantic race in 1960, which was won by Sir Francis Chichester in Gypsy Moth II . Jester came second. She competed in every single subsequent OSTAR, but in 1989 was seriously damaged under sail and lost."
http://www.collars.co.uk/uk_galaxy/info/1/masts_and_spars/6/the_famous_modified_folkboat_jester

Actually this anon has a point. Based on those fuses I’m guessing your house has knob and tube or old bx wires, and the insulation on those is more susceptible to degradation. Open up walls starting from your fuse box until you find the culprit wire

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Do these have a window on the side to see inside to see whether they're blown?
If not, the only way to know is to test.

Testing means using them in another circuit to test continuity.
You could use a multimeter with a continuity check mode
You could put them into a different spot in the fuse block
You could make a circuit with a battery and a wire and a small light bulb (like from a flashlight)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2521677
Another way to test is to stick two wires into a wall socket, and touching them to the sides of the fuse. If the lights turn off, the fuse was good. If they stay on, you have a dead fuse.

>>2521660
Stick the fuses into a circuit that is still working. Or take the fuses from a good circuit and see if they work in that thing you’re holding. If the good circuit stops working with those fuses, and the dead circuit works with fuses from the other functioning circuit, then you have bad fuses.

But you also need to figure out why the fuses popped.

>>2504840
i'm an arborist by profession.
Even modern high quality chains break from time to time. either from misuse, accident or material fault. on average a chain snaps on me every one to two years. luckily modern chainsaws have a chain catcher under the clutch so even when a chain should snap it will immediately arrest on the catcher as it leaves the bar on the underside and be stopped at the catcher immediately - if you are lucky - just dropping down from the catcher harmlessly or slapping the hand guard on the rear grip where it will lose its momentum.
in the worst of cases one of the chain links will get caught and the rest of the chain will come whipping around on the underside of the bar - miss the hand guard and slap the underside of your rear arm, upper leg or your hip if you are holding the saw sideways.
in any case its going to be like a 35mph whip with teeth but it wont keep running and actually be pulled through your flesh as it hits you. wounds from this should be superficial due to the chain loosing most of its energy on the catch.

should you ever pick up a saw with this safety feature missing or damaged, do not use it!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523532
>that larger pool of opportunities might seem to make doing it more probable
yes that is literally how statistics work, if you have a p chance of not cutting your finger off and n number of opportunities to cut your finger off then the probability that in your life you cut your finger off is p^n. This function approaches 0 and for a sufficiently large n always ends with you cutting your finger off. Having a larger number of times where you don't cut a finger off is not going to undo the one time it does happen.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: That's an LG isn't it. Make sure you didn't install the float upside down

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2526350
Also check the pump that's attached to it. It's got a filter that gets clogged and will burn the pump up. And on the floor housing, make sure you follow the directions it says on the front, one side has a magnet. Your float switch also has a filter in it that gets clogged. Take it all apart, clean filter in switch and in pump and put it back together. If the magnet gets hard water crud on it, it doesn't function correctly and doesn't signal the pump to work. Also those pumps are small, and very prone to overheating and burning up. Ive installed a few hundred LG mini split systems and they have that exact float. Always better to not fight gravity and drain normally but sometimes you gotta pump it up and out. Please like and subscribe if this was helpful

posts.com:
What you are holding there is the cladding from an uranium fuel rod, most likely a souvenir from a decommissioned nuclear reactor. They are usually encased in a shielded container and only taken out for educational purposes, with appropriate protection, as they can still be quite "hot" for decades after removal.

Uranium is twice as dense a lead, that's why it is so incredibly heavy.

For proof, here's me holding one that has been decontaminated and is well intact.

Yours appears to be slightly darker in color and shows a significant amount of wear, which indicates that the chromium coating (the shiny finish) has started to erode over time.

This is not good, and you really do not want to hold that with your bare hands.

Well, they're like other heat engines in that to get more power out, you have to raise the compression. >>2509786
There were lots of small improvements made in the 1930s and 1940s when they were more widely used. Unfortunately it seems like most of the knowledge is spread out among communities that don't talk to each other.
For example, there are a few people in Sweden who drive gasifier-fueled cars, and every single one of them use a "stacked pancakes" fabric filter (a large "sock" that is tied off around wireframe discs; used to be canvas cloth in the 1940s, nowadays it's fibreglass). I've never seen for example Americans use fabric filters. Burgers all seem to use the Wayne Keith design, but the details are a trade secret and nobody outside of the US has heard of it.
The basics should be the same though, and there are some obvious things like insulating the hearth (firebox?) and using a heat exchanger for the air intake that I would do.
Another thing would be to convert a modern electric hybrid car. The pros and cons of a gasifier and a battery vehicle means they would complement each other pretty well.

Cyclones filter out particles; they are heavier than the gas and get flung to the outer wall and fall down. The intended use is that they catch most of what comes out so that the filters clog up less often.
Dealing with tar is mostly done, from what I've seen, by minimizing production (right fuel, right temperature) and cooling the gas before it reaches the engine.

>>2516964
I've researched a ton on steam engines, but I've slowly realized there are too many reasons gas engines are superior. Steam engines become very complicated when trying to make them competitive. Most people aren't going to mess with steam boilers (regardless of whether the design is safe), while steam generators require precise controls. Most burner designs have the flame quenched by the boiler/generator with a lot of unburnt fuel appearing as smoke. Ideally, only the exhaust should make contact with the boiler/generator. COGAS (Combined Gas and Steam) engines actually uses the exhaust of a gas turbines to heat a boiler and are among the most efficient combustion engines out there. Going back to using turbines for wood, you'd also use a separator like you would for wood gasifiers, the only difference is all the heat is concentrated in one operation for a higher thermal efficiency.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2517210
>What do you mean by efficiency here?
Power vs. fuel consumption

>having a cold gas at the start of the cycle increases the difference in temperature and therefore pressure.
Having a colder temperature would increase the efficiency of the Carnot cycle if delta T remains constant. However, delta T is purely a function of the amount of fuel burnt, heat capacity, and heat lost to the surroundings. A slower burn is going to lose more heat to the surroundings and an incomplete burn means less fuel burnt. In practice, a slower burn is also going to have less room to expand, and less work will be recovered from it, but a Carnot engine doesn't have any notion of a stroke or expansion ratio.

>>2504527
I wonder how hard it would be to make methanol from wood or coal syngas. You can convert gasoline engines to methanol rather easily.

There's a 99.8% selective methanol synthesis from carbon monoxide and hydrogen with a copper and zinc oxides catalyst at engine cylinder pressures (750~1500 PSI) and kitchen oven temperatures (250C / 500F). It can also work with carbon dioxide and hydrogen or carbon monoxide and water, since CO2 and H2O are intermediates in the process.

Apart from methanol being a gasoline substitute, there's also a simple dehydration reaction with solid acid catalysts (such as gamma alumina) at the same temperature and pressure conditions to produce dimethyl ether. DME has very similar handling characteristics to propane, and is non-toxic and non-corrosive and can be burned for heating and cooking, but also works well in diesel engines (with some conversion required, obviously).

These processes seem like they should be simple enough for small factories run by an individual or small team. Not too much harder than the combination of wood gas conversions and moonshining, and you get fuels that can be handled, stored, sold, and generally used for all the same things as today's standard fuels. You can make them from fire wood in the countryside, coal in coal country, and if solar panels keep getting cheaper, eventually from electrolysis hydrogen and CO2 from chemical capture methods or biomass (you can still get CO2 out of biomass you can't easily burn properly for energy).

>>2518526
>Can we get a description of what's happening here?
Sure. I guess I should add some reference number. Essentially there are 3 circuits:
- the air circuit (hatched) that cools the mantle before being diluted with exhaust and then is fed into the reactor (bottom right)
- the wood gas circuit from the reactor going through tar absorbers and filter before going to the gas turbine, while being cooled by water
- the water circuit that goes in opposite direction to the wood gas circuit, picking up heat throughout the path, before being superheated in the spiral at the bottom of the reactor and then powers a steam turbine.

Lots of details (condencer, recuperator, waste extraction etc) are missing but I hope those are obvious anyway.
Wood in the first tar absorber is fed to the reactor through the yellow square chute at intervals, thus recycling the tar.

Airlocks aren't that complicated, you just need two doors.
>open outer door, combustion chamber is still sealed
>put fuel in loading chamber
>close outer door
>open inner door
>fuel falls into combustion chamber
>close inner door

You can also use a second airlock to remove ash, or you can have one engine with two combustion chambers, so you can open one right up while the system runs on the other.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2519280
>pelletize the wood
Making your own wood pellets is DUMB. I've looked into it. Even if you acquired a mountain of free and sufficiently dry sawdust to work with, bulk pellets are so cheap that it would take you years and years to come out ahead on the price of a wood pelletizer, and that's also not accounting for the time and effort it takes to operate a pelletizing setup. Economies of scale make it impractical to manufacture your own wood pellets and if your concern is off grid living you should stick with regular wood as a heat source.

I get that not everything has to be a strictly economic transaction and that the whole point of hobbies is doing inefficient unpaid labor because you like doing it, but /diy/ pellets are not it. You're not going to have fun watching a pelletizer go brrrrrrrr through tons and tons of sawdust for hours on end.

Either buy it from a company or start your own pellet company. I feel like there are at least a few boomers out there who got sold on the personal pellet mill idea and they're probably all sitting unused in a shed right now.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2522901
Using wood pellets is dumb. It would probably just waste fuel idling/cruising with a gasifier. Just use an engine-driven chipper with a conical pulley to change the speed and adjust the flow of fuel into the engine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523152
The amount of energy it would require to run a wood chipper off your engine would almost certainly negate any advantage you'd get out of the setup. I think the most efficient way to to this would be to somehow automate or at least greatly simplify the process of loading entire logs into the combustion chamber.

As for wood pellets, a lot of the reason for their efficiency advantages don't apply in a gasifier. They're more efficient than a regular wood stove because they burn using a forced convection system, and as a result of the forced convection and their high density they burn at a much higher temperature than regular wood. Forced convection isn't possible in a gasifier and the heat of the reaction doesn't matter much when the process you're using relies on further chemical reactions downstream of the gasifier.

I also question if charcoal in a gasifier is a good idea. The process of making charcoal is essentially the same thing as what's happening in a gasifier, except by separating those processes you'd be losing out on the stream of volatile exhaust gases that come out of the charcoal and relying solely on the carbon monoxide to fuel your car. Using charcoal you're throwing away a good portion of the energy of the wood, and once again the advantage of a higher temperature burn doesn't benefit a gasifier like it would in a furnace.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524004
Here in Sweden we explicitly used normal firewood. The government set standards saying that only specially treated birch was acceptable for cars (called bilved, "car firewood"), but in my parts of the country (very rural, even today if you don't work in forestry or paper manufacturing, you're a farmer) people were just using the exact same firewood they stockpiled for heat in winter, and by all accounts it worked just fine. Some of the wood gas converted cars stayed like that for decades, until the government got stricter about what you were allowed to drive on the road. Even when I was growing up in the 90s my neighbor still had an old wood-gas tractor. He never used it because he also had a modern diesel tractor, but it still ran. He drove it into town for the autumn market festival to show it off a few times. Using firewood probably produces more exhaust or ash than the bilved, because pine doesn't burn as well as birch in the first place, but I don't think that matters too much. Pine firewood is significantly cheaper than birch, let alone birch put through whatever treatment the government wanted people to do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524467
Here in Norway, Alder was the preferred kind of firewood for wood gas generators. Birch is a bit of a cliche and has less energy per kg than many other kinds of wood, but has the advantage of burning quietly without sparking. That is important when using open fire, but less so when using wood gas generators. Pine and connifer have a lot of resin that can cause tiny explosions that throw sparks everywhere, but is perfectly find in a closed oven.

Other than drying, I have no idea what kind of treatment they had for birch.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525662
What you're talking about is a (gravity fed) drip irrigation system, and the design principles and technical ratings for the various types of tubing and emitters used in those systems are all about maintaining and regulating flow rates.
I think you're a bit mixed up about the basics though, the scenario you describe isn't really a problem since the outlets are sized to develop back pressure that lets the entire line fill up In a gravity fed system the overall pressure will fluctuate with the reservoir height, but if the lateral line that taps off the barrel is level and the holes small enough to create back pressure, that pressure will be the same along its entire length.
You'll need to determine the max. flow rate of the full barrel dumping out the outlet pipe unrestricted to start, then size the emitter flow rates and how many to determine how fast it will empty and also how fast it can fill up before overflowing.
Because those drip holes are tiny, filtration is important, little bits of dirt or already growing inside the hoses can easily block them and throw the flow rates way off or disable a branch line entirely.
There's a lot of variables and with gravity feed even more since the pressure changes as the barrel level goes up and down. Just read up on drip irrigation system design or talk to a place that sells the parts and it wont be that hard to get something working.

https://school.sprinklerwarehouse.com/design-install/designing-your-drip-irrigation-system/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525662
>how large the holes should be to help distribute the water through the pipe so it all just doesn't dump out the first hole or two?
If you make the holes on the top of the pipe instead of the bottom it shouldn't matter, as the pipe would need to fill up before the water started coming out of it, which should make it far more likely to evenly distribute the water.

>the type of gear to be made
>the material you want to make the gear out of
>the gear's size
>the number of teeth
>and so on

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2514282
Depends on the type of gear and the tooth profile. For simple spur gears the best options are shaper and horizontal milling machine. A vertical mill could also do the job, but the set up would be a bit awkward and a lot less rigid than a horizontal. In all cases you need an indexing fixture. For milling processes you would need to purchase the correct cutter for your desired pitch. With a shaper you just need a single point tool, which you could probably grind by hand.

All the info you need about 3D-printing: https://pastebin.com/AKqpcyN5
>Your print failed? Go to:
https://www.simplify3d.com/support/print-quality-troubleshooting/

If that doesn't help you solve your print problems, please post:
>A picture of the failed part
>Printer make & model
>Filament type/brand
>Slicer & slicer settings

>What printer should I buy? [Last updated 2022-11-19]
Under 250 USD: kingroon KP3L, Sovol sv01, Creality Ender 3 (v2), Anycubic Mega S
Under 500 USD: Qidi X-One2, Creality CR-10, Anycubic Vyper, Prusa Mini
Under 1000 USD: Prusa i3, Bambu Labs X1
Over 1000 USD: e3d toolchanger, Ultimaker, Qidi X-CF Pro, Build your own Voron, Rat Rig, Prusa XL (lol enjoy the wait)
SLA: Anycubic Photon, Elegoo Mars, Prusa SL1, Formlabs Form 3, Creality HALOT-ONE
Instead of buying a new printer, you could consider building your own: https://reprap.org/wiki/

>Where can I get free things to print?
https://www.thingiverse.com/
https://thangs.com/
https://grabcad.com/
https://google.com/
https://printables.com/
https://www.yeggi.com/

>What CAD software should I use?
Variants of professional parametric CAD programs such as Solidworks (lol paying for software), Fusion360, Inventor, Onshape, TinkerCAD, and AutoCAD may be free depending on your profession, level of piracy and definition of ''free''.
Most anons use Fusion360, but some /g/oobers prefer OpenSCAD or FreeCAD. If you want to do mesh free-forming and modeling, Blender is alright. Also while not necessarily a design program, Meshmixer (free) can be extremely useful for tweaking models to print.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524192
>what build plates do yall recommend
PEI coated spring steel on magnetic base. Smooth and textured handle most materials without needing adhesives or release agents, and those things are easy to apply and clean on a smooth sheet if needed.

>hat fiberglass circuit board material?
Also a good option (G10/garolite), though options for mounting it to a spring steel base are limited, and without that it can be prone to warping with high temp materials like the nylon it's best with unless you get a thick enough sheet to make it too stiff to flex parts off.

>and is PETG any good as "general purpose"?
More or less. It has decent mechanical properties at a decent price, and has good UV resistance and enough heat resistance to handle direct sunlight. It's rather stringy and droopy though, so it's not very suited to aesthetic models.

>how bad does it want to peel and warp?
Worse than PLA, not as bad as polycarbonate. On a (clean) textured PEI sheet it's not an issue for most prints, but large parts with warp/detachment-prone geometry may peel without measures like a brim. Smooth PEI is not recommended because it sticks too well without a release agent. An enclosure may help but it's generally not needed or even useful. One thing about PETG is that the raw material is highly transparent, and so there are interesting transparent options. I've made things that look like cobalt glass.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524636
>Does a bed leveler fix this?
Yes.

>How do those work?
The print head moves a probe to multiple spots around the bed and builds a map of the bed's distortion, which is used to distort the gcode to make it "flat" relative to the maybe-distorted bed. This is usually done before every print.

>Is there a way to see the readings from the leveler?
In principle yes, but not all setups are made to easily show that information.

>Are there ways to get the leveling data into the slicer to see the slicer adapt to the warped bed?
In principle yes, but so far as I know none do that since there's no point, as that route is far inferior to having the printer do it on the fly with the actual just-measured bed distortion.

>Time-saving: Automating replies can help save time and effort by allowing users to quickly and easily respond to a large number of messages.

>Efficiency: Automated replies can help users manage their workload and respond to messages more efficiently, allowing them to focus on other tasks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525190
Underextrusion can be variable depending on how fast the extruder tries to push plastic through. See how the gaps close up at the corners where the print head is moving slower? It looks like your parameters are such that the faster (long straight or gently-curving) moves are fast enough to push the extruder into territory where it underextrudes significantly. One possible solution is to reduce the maximum speed to avoid excessively fast flow rates. Another is to increase nozzle temp to increase the hot end's melt capacity beyond the point where it underextrudes.

it does seem a bit ridiculous that you can't put an equation in the slicer to handle the non-linear flowrate by just telling the extruder to push more plastic at higher requested flowrates, but, whatever. i'll run some test print cubes with high perimeter counts and just focus on eliminating wall gaps without caring about infill overextrusion. printing slower is not an acceptable compromise, but worse surface finish is.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525236
>8.3 mm3/s
This could easily be around the max depending on material, nozzle, hot end, and temperature. If that's PLA and a .4mm nozzle, 218C isn't particularly hot, and while a V6 with a powerful direct drive can force it faster, that doesn't have a whole lot of headroom at that temp.

>what do you suggest I do to fix this? It's a structural print
If it's PLA, temp to ~240 and use a .8mm or so CHT nozzle. That on its own should massively increase the melt capacity. I dial in high flow settings with a vase mode print that I measure to find underextrusion at different parameters.

>>2525238
Note that those flow rates are a combination of extrusion width and the nominal speed for that type of feature, not the actual speed which the print head will attain (which includes acceleration and deceleration). Note that the straight / large-curve high-flow areas there match the underextruded areas in the previous image, and the problem goes away in lower-flow areas and corners (where the print head slows down).

The clear advantage over glass is that you can release prints with just a flex (or most of the time just cooling down too). And you don't need scraping anymore.
As for the glue stick gluestick is usually meant to decrease adhesion to manageable levels, although I havent had much problem without it (using PLA, PLA+, ABS, ABS+ , PETG). But apparently with some people PETG (and TPU) bind too well to the surface and make it very hard to remove. Then again, I have heard the same with PETG+Glass and I never had issues with that either.
It has good adhesion to nearly any material.

Also, the textured PEI doesnt require any additional gluestick, at least with PLA, PLA+ and PETG it works fine. I am going to try ABS+ tonight and see how well it works.

By the way, I am not aware of many people using plain springsteel, as generally its coated in PEI, any info on it?

Spooled it up again and no warping this time around.
Clean your beds gents, and make sure your settings are double checked before printing.

>>2525749
I use Nylon a lot for my job/research, but its such a pain with FDM that I just order/outsource it with SLS printing.
Although it has some good properties (PA12 Nylon is the best material to print compliant mechanisms/flexures out of, hence I use it) it has ome other problems people don't often talk about:
Printed parts get extremely brittle over time from what I think is water exposure.
Nylon has extremely bad creep problems.

Especially the second one severely limits the use cases for mechanisms/constructions which are normally under load/preloaded.
The Nylon will deform under the load, increasing the stress until it breaks. The rate of creep is about twice as bad as most other plastics iirc, but worse is that it doesn't 'flatten out' and keeps creeping until failure.

tl;dr Use Nylon only for mechanisms and structures which aren't preloaded or under constant (significant) load.

>>2525772
>CNC Kitchen made a video where he proves that the strongest layer height is 0.1 mm. 0.5 mm was weaker than 0.1 mm, but 0.1 mm beat ever other layer height. I am also printing this adapter with 100% infill.
Be VERY careful interpreting his results, as he didn't compensate for the flow rate difference between the layer heights. Layer cooling and actual filament temperature exiting the nozzle can be vastly different, and hence explain that difference in strength.


In either case, whether 0.1mm is the strongest or not, I suspect that the actual impact on part strength is negligible. Part design is much, much more important hence making the entire discussion kind of moot.

And perhaps my entire point got a bit muddled in the discussion.

What I am trying to say is, evidence suggesting 0.1mm is the strongest layer height (in general) is weak, and best case shows relatively negligible difference with other layer heights.
What is likely more of impact for your part strenght is the duration of your print. If you print for a longer period of time, you have a higher chance of warping as the part has more time to cool down and create a temperature gradient.
Thus you might be able to reduce warping and increase part strength because of it with larger layer heights. Plus you save some time in your iterations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525724
>It's HTPLA. Does that mean
Its meaning is like "PLA+". There isn't a standardized set of terminology, and manufacturers can call things what they want, more or less. Presumably the manufacturer in this case has changed the recipe a bit from standard PLA in a way that references high temperatures somehow, but you'd have to check the actual spool / supplementary materials to see what it's actually supposed to do.

>it'll crystallize further and get more transparent?
PLA (and plastics in general) become less transparent when they crystallize. Annealing PLA changes the amorphous as-printed plastic to a crystallized form that is much more heat resistant. "HTPLA" is generally not more heat resistant than regular PLA after annealing, but there's supposed to be something in it that makes that process easier somehow. The kind I use (Volcano PLA) anneals with virtually no distortion, which is what usually causes trouble with the endeavor. Burying a part in sand is intended to reduce distortion.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524432
Replacement generally has to be done the way the chair was originally done, if it used mat than you use mat, if it was woven than you weave it. Mat is simple, like replacing window screen but when it starts to fail it goes quickly. Woven is more work, a little cheaper and if a strand or two breaks the chair will generally not care much. So rip the cane completely out of one and see if it has holes or a groove. Order the supplies and have at it, expect a chair or two to be failures before you get the technique down. If you are weaving then I would get a book, having those nice color photos well arranged with descriptions of the process well arranged and laid out for you to reference while you work will be very helpful. Most libraries should have a caning book or a chair making/repair book or a canoe making book (canoes often have woven cane seats so your butt can dry out). Videos will suck for this since you will find you need to jump back and fourth a lot. You should be able to do all 8 for less than what that guy was charging for one, but you should also be able to find someone cheaper to do it, try upholstery shops. Caning chairs is enjoyable and not a bad skill to learn. Personally I prefer rush seats.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524445
Weaving a chair seat is not difficult and does not require much in the way of tools, some tapered dowels, something to soak the can in, something to cut the cane with, about it. Matting is fairly standardized, don't need manufacturers ID or anything here, if you want it the same then you just measure the cane size and order mat of the same, sold by the yard.

>>2518032
Depends on the task, but apparently I am an odd one given the replies so far, but I like ratcheting screwdriver with bits. But it is hard to find a good one, honestly still looking the good one broke after several years and the new versions aren't as good. Lots of them now have hollow handles for storage, but that really weakens it as the handle bends and sometimes even breaks in my hand when I grip too hard, the old metal ones never did that. Reason I still like them is I have had projects where I drive in hundreds and hundreds of screws by hand. I had bits wear out which lead to other problems. By switch to fresh bits as I go I didn't have to keep buying screw drivers which cost more then a box of bits. It also lets me change to other types as the job had 8 screw types, so finding a comfy handle each item was annoying. Lastly the ratcheting helped for some oddly positioned screws, but you want fine gear teeth so you don't waste a lot of the rotation.

I also have regular screwdrivers as well for the more detail work as they aren't loose.

No but car to be legal car running and head lights need to be USDOT approved and not all LEDs are...some actually say right on them "not legal for street use" or "for off road use ONLY".

For my old ass Corolla I can just put high beam bulbs into my low beams, just gotta shave off the plastic bumpers in the socket to make it fit. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525351
Bending is a function of force and length on one hand, and stiffness on the other.
Want to reduce bending? Reduce force. You can't lower gravity, so reduce the weight first. Second, reduce length of the bending member to a minimum. If you add another file cabinet to that setup you reduce the span by a foot or so, which should cut sag by a third if not a half.
To increase stiffness, simply replace that weak wood with a one inch thick piece of steel. May need some reinforcement on the file cabinets though. Carbon fibre would be another option, but a bit expensive. Stiffness, however, is a function of both material and geometry. If you want a stiffer panel, increasing the thickness only does so much. You would make it much, much stiffer by placing a supporting beam at the rear of the panel.
Finally, you could put a leg in the middle to prevent sag altogether, but that would probably not look as good and intrude on leg room.

In all seriousness, a 1x4'' piece of wood underneath the table surface, at the wall end, should support it more than enough. Just make sure than the tabel surface overlaps the cabinets by about an inch or so, so you can screw or glue the surface and beam together.

>>2516819
Then apply at an electrical company for an apprenticeship. Apply at a few of them. Commercial would be best because that's what most of the code book is. Then either industrial or service work. Service, you'll learn repair and more about electricity in general. Residential new construction is a fast paced game where only the fastest person is fast and everyone else is slow, every job is bid under every other residential company because Fuck quality workmanship, only a few chapters in the code book are needed for the job , so you won't learn much. I started out in residential, because of my father getting me a job and doing side work since I was 12 or so, and trying to learn the code with out ever seeing a transformer, main distribution panel, running conduit and shit like that, it was hard to understand what all the codes were even talking about. Got my journeyman, quit residential and went commercial. Then 2008 happened and commercial shut down in my area. Had to go back to residential and work for a dipshit, who I think sucked a LOT of dicks to get where he was at. That pissed me off enough to get my contractors and start my own company. I do high end remodel now. Have to use my brain troubleshooting and planning and I enjoy that. The only drawback is attic work occasionally.

Figure out how high you want to go and get a job in that field. Figure out what you like doing as well. Industrial is different than commercial is different than residential. A lot of guys are just happy with a paycheck and don't mind running conduit and pulling circuits forever. Some want to move up to foreman. Some, can't do the job and they get stuck roughing in walls and devicing out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've got a 130 year old two story house that's badly in need of a lot of things. I have a rough idea of the most sensible sequence in which things need to be done. A new water heater is on the list, but it's waiting on an electrical overhaul, which in turn is waiting on other things. Unfortunately, the regulator on my water heater seems to have begun to leak gas into my kitchen, and I don't think I want to spend $200 (the price of a new regulator) to repair a unit I plan on throwing away as soon as possible. I'm therefore faced with installing a water heater before my electrical system is ready for it.

I want to replace my 40 gallon gas water heater with a tankless electric one. I want it to be electric precisely so that it can't malfunction and leak explosive gas into my kitchen, and tankless because there's not a good location for a water heater in my house, which was built without closets. It's currently in the corner of the kitchen, where it's a major eyesore. Another reason to go with an electric heater is that I'd like to perform as much of the installation as possible myself and to be able to service it myself moving forward, and I am much more comfortable working with electricity than with gas.

A 27 kW water heater calls for 3 x 40 A breakers and pulls up to 112.5 A. A have a 200 A main panel with room for those breakers. Unfortunately, the typical load on that panel is pretty high thanks to my reliance on resistive heating (electric radiators - no ductwork yet) and to the fact that it supplies not only a large-ish house but also a large-ish workshop. I'm probably using 80 - 100 amps for heat, and I can see myself using 25 A for other stuff if I'm working in the shop. If, say, two other people are using hot water at the same time, I can see that 200 amp capacity being exceeded.

The worst that can happen is that I flip my main breaker, right? Should I just fix my gas one?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525534
>Should I just fix my gas one?
If I were you, I would just get on facebook marketplace, craigslist or whatever the locally relevant apps/sites are in your area and buy a cheap used gas water heater. In my area at least, you can usually snag one for around 100$. This would be a fast, cheap, and functional move-- even if it's only a temporary fix and you wind up doing a different solution later.

Electric tankless units are kind of wacky because of their huge power requirements. Swapping to a 400A main panel plus the cost of the thicc cable run for the tankless is going to wind up being expensive as fuck, and you'd never break even on the energy savings.
The only reason that tankless make sense is for certain use cases where you actually need to use hundreds of gallons of hot water in an hour. (or niche applications where you need the especially hot 185f water they can provide for commercial service)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525534
First off, are you sure there's something wrong with the regulator? It could be as simple as a bad connection. Start with some soapy water to find where the leak is coming from.

Your worst case here is that you rip out your gas unit, the elec heater doesn't work without more power, and you have no hot water until your electrical overhaul is done. If that's an acceptable risk to you, by all means, save the $200. Personally I'd take the risk because I like cold showers.

Finally, I would crunch the numbers and figure out your energy costs. How much does the on-demand unit cost to run, and how long will it take to pay for itself. I suspect it won't, and you seem to be focusing on saving money here?

Anyway, good luck. And don't be afraid of gas. Just get a little sensor alarm

>>2523823
>Funny enough the anon giving him shit ended up making this guy do a better job. You ought to honestly thank the guy who gave you the truth about your gay ring

LOL, that was me and it's thanks enough to see that he took the critique in the spirit in which it was intended and reconsidered where it was at in the process and is happy to have done so.
Just for the record, there's nothing wrong with just making things functional or not perfecting diy skills when problem solving is the goal, but the whole point and function of jewelry is to be aesthetically pleasing to as high a degree as possible, literally something the owner will treasure.
"Good enough" really doesn't apply the way it does with a garage shelf or other utilitarian objects. It's OK to not be a master on your first try; the point is you may still suck on try 35 and the solution in general and for any individual piece is to suck it up and do the work that's missing.
The good news is that that's almost always finishing work so with minimal planning and common sense something that's not that great can be greatly improved, it's just really boring and tedious work which is why people blow it off.
I'm proud of the OP for rising to the challenge and he should take pride in it too, regardless of how it's received as a gift.

Probably a DIY slab that is too thin.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
"Slab jacking" is a thing, but I've never known anyone to diy it.
Basically drill holes in the existing slab & pump concrete slurry underneath, until you level out the pieces. When it cures the soil underneath will be stabilized. It's very common for sidewalks, driveways, but you can fix concrete floors with it too. It's not cheap, but it's less than tearing out the entire floor & repouring.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2522093
I used a laptop and a mini projector to put the images on plywood and raced the lines with a sharpie. Then I rough cut around them with a jigsaw, used the scrollsaw right up to the outer lines, sanded the edges with 120 and attached stakes to the back with a nailgun and woodglue. I painted and went over the sharpie lines with black on a thin craft brush. Some of them got imperfections from drips of other paint bit I can touch them up later.

What do you guys think about this house?

I'm considering building something similar, but I have no experience living in an open house like that. One one hand, it does look beautiful and comfy, but on the other, I don't know how practical it is.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G__DpXRsJXE

Here are some of the concerns I have:
- There seem to be 2 living rooms, one close to the kitchen where the TV is, and one left from the entrance with no TV and large book in the middle. Do spaces like that end up being used at all? Or would it just be an unusable area I heat for no reason?
- A lot of space seems wasted between the main door, stairs and living room.
- The bathroom is divided from the living room with only 1 door. Sound would pass through, no?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525923
Open spaces are neat until you realize whatever mess you make in one of the areas affects the whole floor with varying degrees.

For example cooking. Frequent use of the frying pan will leave fatty residue everywhere even with a fume hood. Simply look at the top of your kitchen shelves after a year.

Also heating such spaces is a bitch. Walls or dividers would hinder airflow and capture heat in areas which this way is next to impossible without selective floor heating.

Getting alone time is also harder. Getting some distance to do something in silence and solitute, be it taxes, reading or something or just taking a nap on the couch is also hampered.

Connecting some spaces is convenient. Like the living room and a seperate eating area. However inviting the problems of wholly seperate rooms with their unique use cases and problems is imo ill advised.

posts.com:
>Spray water bottle with primer
>Wrap bottle in tape over area to be sprayed
>Tape stencil to bottle
>Carefully cut stencil and tape off bottle (you're going to scratch the bottle this way, don't press too hard and change blades frequently)
>remove stencil and tape from area to be sprayed
>spray bottle with paint
>Wait for paint to dry, spray again
>Remove tape carefully
>Clear coat bottle so paint doesn't rub off on everything

Way more work than it's worth. Get the design printed as a vinyl sticker instead.

>>2525245
>heated everywhere using floor heating, but keeping some rooms colder, for example living room, bedrooms and bathrooms at 24 C, and halls at 18 C. Does it make a huge difference?
This is a bad example because if you have decent insulation in the buildings outer envelope, then it's unlikely that you would see such a large variation of 6C difference between the various rooms and the hall.

You're going to have to be a lot more specific about the particulars of the design and the outside climate in order to try to get even a rough estimate of energy usage differences.

It's a lot easier to simply look at the energy usage difference between an entire house kept at 18c vs 24c and then realize that in your example the energy usage would fall somewhere in between these two numbers.

Spoiler alert: it's not going to be a large amount of energy saved IF you're not in an arctic climate and if the building envelope has excellent insulation. It's negligible.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525274
You can estimate the heating need of the building by considering the building envelope area and the thermal conductivity (watts per square meter per degree kelvin) of the various building assemblies.

When you have a well insulated structure, you can wind up with a "diminishing returns" situation with continuing to add more and more insulation, because the heat losses will be absolutely dominated by losses through the windows and doors and through the ventilation air.

If you had a house with no doors or windows and no ventilation that was a 250m2 building with 4m high walls made from good 200mm thermobrick and 100mm styro board, along with a decent floor and attic insulation -- it could be kept 24C inside when it's 0C outside with only a few hundred watts worth of heat pump usage. The doors, windows, and makeup air would dominate a calculation like this.

I invite you to search about doing heat loss calculation for houses... in the USA we have the ANSI "Manual J" which describes the sizing of HVAC equipment based on the insulance and conductance of various building assemblies along with taking into account the ventilation requirements and heat produced from appliances etc. I'm sure there is something similar in the EU standards.

You can run some quick numbers for a house with your specifications and you will find that keeping the bedrooms and hallways at different temps as well as having high ceilings will make little difference in your ultimate heating bills as long as the building is well insulated.

The Castle Doctrine is incorporated into Connecticut law governing the use of physical force in defense of premises. This law states that a person who possesses or controls a premises, or is licensed or privileged to be on such premises, is justified in using reasonable physical force upon another person when he or she reasonably believes it to be necessary to prevent or stop someone from criminally trespassing. Deadly force is reasonable only (1) to defend oneself or another; (2) when one reasonably believes deadly force is necessary to prevent an attempt by the trespasser to commit arson or any violent crime; or (3) to the extent the person reasonably believes it is necessary and only to prevent or terminate an unlawful entry by force into his or her dwelling or place of work

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Here's something to know about saws: there are 3 types of panel saws to be aware of.
1. The crosscut saw. This saw has sharp points to cut the wood fibers when sawing across the gain. You're only going to find this in specialty woodworking stores for a very high price, or at a flea market.
2. The rip cut saw. This saw has a more chisel-like face on its teeth to shave the fibers when sawing with the grain. Same availability as the crosscut saw.
3. The hardware store saw, also called the hardpoint saw. This is basically a crosscut saw that they market as also being capable of doing rip cuts. They are lying. They're quite good at crosscuts though albeit usually with horrible handles. You can't resharpen them because the teeth are impulse hardened but hey last a very long time, especially considering the usually absurdly low price.
Since you're almost certainly getting a hardware store saw you going to want to stay away from rips as much as is reasonable. If you've ever wondered why sawing is so hard, it's probably because you used a shitty/wrong saw.

posts.com:
>>2522873
A reasonably good quality jigsaw can do it, use a narrow scroll blade for tight curves and a wider one for straight cuts to avoid it taking off at an angle...longer straight cuts can be roughed in in the middle with a circular saw and the ends of blind cuts finished with the jigsaw for the same reason.
The other option would be to make a template of the repeating shape and use a router with a straight bit and a guide collar.
Personally I'd use the saw for that number since it's quick and easy and any small deviations will just make it look more period authentic ...too perfect can stick out and look weird.
Just be methodical, cut every incidence of one hole shape or curve in one operation then move to the next group rather than starting at one end and working in a line; it will be more uniform and of one piece and minimizes forgetting some detail until someone notices when its up on the building.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2522886
Also when you get into tighter curves and inside corners turn off any orbital feature so the blade is cutting straight up and down like a scroll saw.
Most scroll blades for jigsaws are set up this way but double check all the blades you use to make sure the teeth are oriented to cut on the upstroke which also has keep them from wandering off track.
Depending on the material and shapes you can also sometimes use hole saws to locate and reproduce curves and then connect the dots between them saving time and risk of broken jigsaw blades.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523025
>pressure treated

PT is for ground contact, makes no sense here.
Cypress is the preferred timber species for that kind of exterior trim and has the best mix of even grain structure, dimensional stability and pest/rot resistance for exterior trim. Cedar is another alternative.
Common fir/ hemlock construction lumber with alternating hard/soft grain is a nightmare to try to make this kind of scrolling detail in, and is also more likely to warp and crack across short cross grain details.
If you can't do the cost of cypress or cedar, spruce and pine work too.
Regardless of what gets used, prime and paint every square inch of it prior to installation; nailing it up raw and just painting the faces/edges is a recipe for cupping and warping and snapping off details.
If you want to treat it with something like cuprinol, after cutting it is the time to do it.

Also a relative newfag here (at least when it comes to house stuff), I've found it helpful to just buy things as you need them Because it depends what you're trying to do.
At the very least, get yourself:
>A step ladder
>A longer ladder
>A screwdriver (or set)
>A hammer
>A tape measure
>A spirit level
>Some pliers
You can now assemble furniture and hang paintings. Depending on your garden situation you might also want some basic tools for that.

One thing I'll say is that you probably don't need a drill yet and can get by with an impact driver. Also, Ryobi is great for our application. You probably don't need anything fancier.

Also, Youtube is great. The Canadian boomer at Home RenoVision DIY is a decent starting point.

posts.name: Anonymous

People vastly overestimate how many tools they need as a "homeowner" especially starting out.
Youll soon realize that the cliche of shit breaking all the time just isnt true (unless you bought an actual dilapidated house)
If something breaks, you arent going to be able to "fix" it without going to the hardware store anyways.
Buy the tools you need as you are buying the replacement stuff.

Bare minimum
Multi Bit Screwdriver + Adjustable Wrench + Slipjoint Pliers will do 90% of the random "fixes" (aka tighten something thats loose) in the house.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524503
It would be dumb to pretend that no VOCs present health/ environmental hazards (not that anyone's done that) but it's equally dumb to lump any and all VOCs together as health/environmental hazards or to pretend that restrictions on them and off-gassing levels are based on the hazards of direct exposure-

"...the regulations that we have promulgated for VOCs in architectural coatings and consumer products are in place only because many VOCs photochemically react in the atmosphere to produce ozone, a component of smog."

To be clear, that doesn't mean direct exposure is "safe"-

"some chemicals that are toxic are exempt from the VOC regulations because they are not considered to be photochemically reactive. Therefore, some products that are labeled as "no VOC" or "low VOC" under the CAA can actually contain volatile organic chemicals that are toxic, sometimes at high levels.

In addition, the concept of lowering "total VOC" (TVOC) does not always assure safer products because the individual VOCs that make up TVOC can vary widely in their toxicity. While it is probably prudent to use products with lower VOC levels, it does not assure that the products are any better (and they may even be worse) than products with higher VOC levels."

Point is that "VOC" and "offgassing" get tossed around like they're always a direct threat, but lumber, houseplants, many foods like fruit and humans offgas VOCs.

I would get a pair of hardened wire strippers and cut out the part that has Au in it. Use wirestrippers to break the diamonds out of the ring and make sure you dont loose the pieces.

You will need an induction furnace and a crucible, check what you can use (zirconia, alumina, and graphite are common). Heat the metal in the crucible then pour it into a thin wire. Work the wire into the shape you want then heat to melt accordingly.

checkin in. pardon the trip but I think it'll be useful. I had a good evening the other day with my king-of-random blast furnace. I melted aluminum over lump charcoal with a hairdryer in a silicon-graphite crucible. I made 2 ingots one run, and two more the next. I attempted a carbothermal reduction of ferrous oxide in a cermaic crucible I bought for $1 at goodwill, and another attempt in a glass crucible from goodwill. The ceramic crucible cracked, and the glass crucible melted, but didn't crack, but I didn't get a reduction. I cooked some pork chops and I beat on a railroad spike for a while until I ran out of charcoal. It was all really retarded and a lot of fun. I did it for like 6 hours. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2477882
Induction doesn't require material to be magnetic, just conductive. Energy transfer is more efficient when magnetic, but steel will become non-magnetic when sufficiently heated. If anything you would prefer a non-magnetic, non conductive crucible such that the metal is directly heated rather than indirectly through walls of crucible. Big challenge in getting up to temperature is all of the heat losses due to radiation and convection. For cast iron / cast steel graphite-based crucibles are most commonly used. Not straight graphite but don't know the exact formulation.

Oh, it's you. You need to learn thermodynamics. The steel furnaces are lined with ceramic liners (usually some cementatious clay). This + the steel's ability to be cooled by air is enough to avoid melting.

Whe the clay liner fails you get all the molten metal shooting out the hole in the now-melted steel.

The lid and liner are very thick relqtovely speaking; this insulates the melt inside.

posts.com:
>>2488793
Most of the iridium on Earth (probably) ended up bonded to iron and is still molten beneath the crust, which is the reason there is so little accessible to us.
We do mine it, it does occur naturally, it's just rare stuff.
There's more of it in meteorites than in the layers of Earth we have access to, that's not unusual, that's true of numerous elements.
This makes it useful as one of the indicators of large meteorite impacts, one of many valid and observed indicators.
That's about it. It's useful stuff, been produced and used commercially for just shy of 200 years now.
It's just uncommon in the top layers of the Earth's crust where we can access it.

In the scale of the universe, it's an element with a fairly high atomic number (77), so it's going to be relatively uncommon compared to "most" elements with lower atomic numbers. This isn't a perfect rule, but it's a decent rule of thumb.
The reasons why are complex, you'd be wanting to read up on cosmic nucleosynthesis to get an idea of how various elements were formed by the Big Bang, exploding stars, merging stars, cosmic rays, all kinds of neat stuff. Isotopes and stability play a big role in this, certain elements don't have known stable isotopes, and are so "unlikely" to exist in nature they may well not exist anywhere in the universe they aren't actively being produced by an intelligence with the intention of producing them, like we do.

posts.com:
>>2490205

The most viable iridium deposits on Earth are massive, fuck-off huge ancient impact craters from around the time the crust was forming an stabilizing. those are actually a big part of the reason Africa has so much mineral wealth in general. Outside of that, you find a some in old volcanic complexes that have eroded away.

You can pull "native" iridium from copper and platinum refining in minuscule amounts, or in very rare igneous deposits as microscopic bare nuggets alloyed with other metals. There's a couple iron-iridium minerals and one copper-iridium mineral that forms naturally as inclusions in deposits of other platinum and iron-group minerals, but they're vanishingly small - 5 - 10 micron in diameter, and very very sparse.

Basically, the tiny amount that we currently produce is all produced "accidentally" as a byproduct of refining other rare metals. most of the viable sources occur as a "side product" of mining gold conglomerates in Africa and gold sands in North America.

it's a damn shame, as iridium complexes might end up being some of the most compelling phosphors and catalysts ever discovered, but no one in their right mind is ever going to suggest large scale industrialization of an iridium-based chemistry. Even metallurgical uses are basically all luxury items at this point, with some very low volume extreme-condition industrial uses.

>>2496976
The power requirements are MASSIVE. Always used for small batch metallurgy or low melting temp metals that need VERY carefully controlled temperature profiles. Large batch Induction heaters are almost always used as reheaters or preheaters these days. Arc heating or gas fired is still preferred.

Induction smelters are great for fine control and quick batching but are more expensive than any other heat source.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2499296
Heat red hot. Oil quench with pliers no swishing (firing tip down). Heat at AT LEAST 500°F (more like 600 if you can) until it shows a good darkening yellow color.

That should give you a proper hardened profile with enough tempering to not explode.

Google search (O1 tool steel tempering graph) and aim for 50-55HRC if you want more info.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2508422
Easy recipe: take some generic 1020 or 4140 or something (a proper quenchable tool steel if you are brave) and cut it into small chunks (or buy some steel shot if lazy). Take some cast iron powder. Pack the chunks VERY WELL and tightly into a crucible and seal it or at least borax the shit out of the top. Bring to half way between the melting temperature of the cast iron and of the steel.

The cast iron melts and diffuses into the steel. Eventually the chemistry of the steel and castiron average out until it is a mass of solid chunks and intermingled semi-solid mushy not-quite-cast iron. Consistency of a concrete that is a little too dry. You need to only heat it long enough to get this diffusion about half way - if it becomes 100% solid you went too long. Allow this to slowly cool so that everything diffuses well together but maintains a distinct pattern.

The steel you used is mostly the original steel (now higher carbon) but is all bound with a web of very carbidic pearlite, carbides, and other high-Si intermetallics.

>>2513066
Anything that is carbide forming (tool steels, bearing steels) resists carbon diffusion through martensite (huge Ni/Cr atoms + small Mn/V atoms fug up the diffusion) so you can develop a decorative oxide layer but maintain strength and hardness.

Look for "impact grade" tool steels if you're making a sword.

>>2516112
Acid reacts with and rapidly corrodes the surface of metal. Can be used in combination with a resist to make some sort of pattern or just applied generally to expose virgin metal, as for weld testing.
You can get both sulfuric and hydrochloric acid from a well stocked hardware store. Sulfuric is sold as drain cleaner, and HCL is sold for cleaning concrete and masonry labeled as muriatic acid. Even the acetic acid in cleaning vinegar will work, albeit more slowly. Copper sulfate, which is sold for horticulture and aquaculture can also be used for etching, but I'm not sure of the specifics of the process.
Don't hurt yourself

>>2518598
With PLA I've had the best luck turning the mold upside down and melting at 400C. Then turn up to 450C which will cause anything left to burn out. The kitchen oven won't quiet do it, so I made my own out of a stovetop heating element, inswool, PID, and a washing machine drum. I found a 3D printing filament "Mold-Lay" that is low temp enough to be melted out in the kitchen oven, but still makes a smoky mess and more expensive than PLA. I usually use 50% sand 50% plaster. The 45 minute plaster works better than the 15 minute plaster (and is cheaper too). Use a paint brush to paint the mixture on the surface before fully submerging to make sure it fills all the nooks and crannies. Using 356 aluminum rather than potluck aluminum will give much better results (found someone on Ebay selling for $3/lb).

>>2521382
Instead of just putting a model in plaster and burning it out you make a multi-layered shell of porous ceramic glaze and essentially sand. You then can preheat the entire mold after burnout and fill with metal then let slow cool in the furnace.

The finer the model (wax is historically used for ease of burn out, modern SLA works great but takes longer to burn) the better the end product.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524823
Not sure if it's any use but I have a bit of experience. You shouldn't be seeing blue with just the fuel on, you also don't have to make a huge acetylene flame before lighting the oxy, I'd say once the flame has volume and is putting out thick black smoke then you're good for the oxy. When you're tuning the flame people talk about a neutral flame but it's kinda hard for a beginner to grasp what that means, basically you watch the little flame needle (or needles depending on your nozzle) sticking out the hole (or holes) in the nozzle tip, you want that needle to be as long as possible without the flame flickering or changing color, the base of the flame should be blue with the yellow and orange further out, if you try to make the needles too long the flame will become a bright white and jet out of the nozzle in a sort of thin beam so that's a good way to tell you that you went too far. Sometimes gauges are weird so I can't really help you there, used to have a gauge at the shop that would correctly read the oxygen psi at the pressures we needed but the needle would never drop below 20 psi even when we turned it off. Make sure you have a welding/brazing tip and use good filler, keep the filler shielded by the outer flame not the the inner needle and don't dip that needle into the puddle, that's pretty much it for mild steel, it's kinda like tig when you start going.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You don't necessarily need composite if you get pvc with foam insulation in the frame channels. Things like low e glazing help (some people think they're a scam, I haven't made up my mind yet). Argon gas is also pretty standard these days but that dissipates.

Dual pane glass should be fine. Biggest thing is making sure it's installed right and knowing that if you do go with a purely vinyl window there will be sag down the line with operable windows.
As for the patio door a slider will always be less efficienct than French doors, but French doors are typically more expensive. If you go with French doors pay the extra for fiberglass as they are typically better insulated than steel, and steel dent/rusts/demlainates much easier.

You won't get anything quickly unless your shit is all whatever is standard sizes in bongland, and that's only for the door. There are no "standard" window sizes but you might get lucky and have your RO be close to sizes that manufacturers run in bulk.

Quickest fix is plastic wrap and blankets over the windows.

>>2518073
With an SDR you can make your own "cell tower" and nearby phones will connect to it, as it will have the strongest signal. This is how the Stingray (google it) works. If you don't have it pass on traffic, then it will essentially just cause all the connected phones to have no service.

>>2518279
It's literally the radio equivalent of making an extremely loud noise so that people can't talk to each other.
If you use it in any kind of stationary setting, it will be extremely easy to track down, and likely will be automatically triangulated by radio monitoring stations designed to guard against this exact kind of thing.

>>2518218
Based. Bluetooth is even better because you can simply send a "deauth packet" (WiFi terminology, but still). You dont have to scream over top of the signal, instead you're just making the bluetooth devices think that the other side has chosen to terminate the transmission.

posts.com:
Just target 3rd Order IM Frequencies in your area f1 + (f1 - f2) and you will give everyone heart ache
Protip, the low bands are carrier prioritized highest so if you target stuff like b12 & b14 it won't be able to "escalate" carriers to higher bands
>t. Cell Tech

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2521460
I'll Elaborate
lets use b12 as an example
you have a downlink carrier frequency between 728(f2)Mhz and 746(f1)Mhz
is the (IM3) is 764 Mhz and 706 Mhz
since devices have to be listening to that whole swath, the difference between f1 and f2 creates noise in IM3
best part is that its "natural" unlike "overpowering" a carrier frequency like traditional jammers since you are just introducing noise to impact the QoS and even >100 dBc can ruin service handling to the point that not even calls can be placed.
